question.title: In Java, can I create an instance of an anonymous subclass from a Class object?

node.contents: I have a factory method that creates objects to be used in unit tests. These objects all derive from the same base class:

astNode.text: I have a factory method that creates objects to be used in unit tests. These objects all derive from the same base class:

elements.contents: public static <T extends BaseEntity> T modMake(Class<T> clazz) { try { return clazz.newInstance(); } catch (InstantiationException e) { // Should never happen throw new AssertionError(e); } catch (IllegalAccessException e) { // Should never happen throw new AssertionError(e); } }

comments.text: // Should never happen throw new AssertionError(e); } catch (IllegalAccessException e) { // Should never happen throw new AssertionError(e); } }

node.contents: Now I want to override a getter method from that base class, but just for the tests. I would usually do that with an anonymous class, for example (Node being one of the subtaypes of BaseEntity):

astNode.text: Now I want to override a getter method from that base class, but just for the tests. I would usually do that with an anonymous class, for example (Node being one of the subtaypes of BaseEntity):

elements.contents: public static Node nodMake() { return new Node() { @Override public long ixGet() { return 1; } }; }

units.rawText: public static Node nodMake() { return new Node() { @Override public long ixGet() { return 1; } }; }

node.contents: Can I do that in the function using the Class argument, too?

astNode.text: Can I do that in the function using the Class argument, too?

node.contents: I don't think there is any way to do that. You probably need to look into bytecode manipulators if you really need to go that route. Javassist and BCEL are a couple of choices.

astNode.text: I don't think there is any way to do that. You probably need to look into bytecode manipulators if you really need to go that route. Javassist and BCEL are a couple of choices.

node.contents: Interesting. I hadn't used Java like this, yet.

astNode.text: Interesting. I hadn't used Java like this, yet.

node.contents: I'm now actually using EasyMock and it rocks. Thanks!

astNode.text: I'm now actually using EasyMock and it rocks. Thanks!

node.contents: Lose your factory method and use a mocking API like EasyMock to achieve the behavior you describe.

astNode.text: Lose your factory method and use a mocking API like EasyMock to achieve the behavior you describe.

node.contents: Your code will then end up something like this:

astNode.text: Your code will then end up something like this:

elements.contents: long returnValue = 12; Node nodeMock = createMock(Node.class); expect(nodeMock.ixGet()).andReturn(returnValue); replay(nodeMock); //add test code here verify(nodeMock);

units.rawText: long returnValue = 12; Node nodeMock = createMock(Node.class); expect(nodeMock.ixGet()).andReturn(returnValue); replay(nodeMock); //add test code here verify(nodeMock);

node.contents: To answer Hanno's question on how this works:

astNode.text: To answer Hanno's question on how this works:

node.contents: It depends on whether your mocking an interface or a class.

astNode.text: It depends on whether your mocking an interface or a class.

node.contents: The case of the interface is simple (code-wise), it uses what's called a dynamic proxy, which is part of core Java.

astNode.text: The case of the interface is simple (code-wise), it uses what's called a dynamic proxy, which is part of core Java.

node.contents: In the case of the class it's doing the bytecode manipulation that @Jonathan mentions in his answer, just behind a nice API.

astNode.text: In the case of the class it's doing the bytecode manipulation that @Jonathan mentions in his answer, just behind a nice API.

node.contents: Both the above mechanisms allow the method calls to be intercepted and EasyMock simply responds based on the expectations you've setup.

astNode.text: Both the above mechanisms allow the method calls to be intercepted and EasyMock simply responds based on the expectations you've setup.
